elements.content: Seven two- or three-dimensional (2D or 3D) coordination polymers have been synthesized by tetrakis­(4-pyridyloxymethylene)­methane (TPOM) with V-shaped 4,4′-oxybis­(benzoicacid) (H2oba), 4,4′-sulfonyldibenzoic acid (H2sdb), 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­bis­(benzoic acid) (H2hfipbb), 4,4′-dicarboxydiphenylamine (H2ddpa), and 4,4′-dicarboxy-ethyl diphenylamine (H2dedpa) in the presence of nitrates of transition metal in H2O/DMF systems, namely, {[Co2(TPOM)­(oba)2(H2O)2]­·(H2O)8} n (1), {[Cd2(TPOM)­(oba)2­(H2O)2]­·(H2O)4­(DMF)1.5} n (2), {[Ni2(TPOM)­(oba)2(H2O)2]­·(H2O)5} n (3), {[Co2(TPOM)­(hfipbb)2]­·(H2O)3} n (4), {[Cd2(TPOM)­(dedpa)2]­·(H2O)4­(DMF)2} n (5), {[Co2(TPOM)­(sdb)2]­·(H2O)3} n (6), {[Co2(TPOM)­(ddpa)2]} n (7). Complexes 1–3 have similar structures, possessing 3D self-penetrated frameworks. Complex 4 is also a self-penetrated 3D framework containing meso-helix [Co­(hfipbb)] n chains. Complex 5 reveals a 2-fold interlocked 2D → 2D network. For complex 6, only three pyridyl groups coordinated to Co­(II) ions in one TPOM ligand, while for complex 7, only two pyridyl groups coordinated to Co­(II) ions in one TPOM ligand. In addition, magnetic, fluorescence, and UV–vis properties of these complexes have been studied.

In addition, magnetic, fluorescence, and UV-vis properties of these complexes have been studied.

elements.content: Great interest has been focused on the rapidly expanding field of the construction of novel functional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their intriguing aesthetic architectures and great widespread applications in photochemical areas, molecular magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and molecular sorption. The designability of MOFs provides a unique opportunity to regulate the structures and comprehend the structure–activity relationships. Furthermore, the better chemical and thermal stability can render more suitable materials to apply in a practical process. Even though great progress has been made, it is still a difficult task to construct new frameworks with specific structures and properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Great interest has been focused on the rapidly expanding field of the construction of novel functional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their intriguing aesthetic architectures and great widespread applications in photochemical areas, molecular magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and molecular sorption. The designability of MOFs provides a unique opportunity to regulate the structures and comprehend the structure-activity relationships. Furthermore, the better chemical and thermal stability can render more suitable materials to apply in a practical process. Even though great progress has been made, it is still a difficult task to construct new frameworks with specific structures and properties.

elements.content: As we all know, the selection of organic ligands is very important in the construction of coordination polymers. As an important family of multidentate N-donor ligands, organic pyridyl ligands have been extensively employed in the preparation of MOFs with multidimensional networks and interesting properties. Tetrakis­(4-pyridyloxy-methylene) methane (TPOM) is a flexible polypyridyl ligand; it has been justified as an efficient and versatile organic building unit for construction of coordination architectures by the Ma and Du et al. groups. However, it is believed that the MOFs containing TPOM with various structures and characters could still be achieved by changing assembly environments and strategies. It is an effective method to introduce auxiliary polycarboxylate linkers in preparing mixed ligands MOFs, which have been proven by Zheng’s group, Ma’s group, Du’s group, and other groups.

However, it is believed that the MOFs containing TPOM with various structures and characters could still be achieved by changing assembly environments and strategies. It is an effective method to introduce auxiliary polycarboxylate linkers in preparing mixed ligands MOFs, which have been proven by Zheng's group, Ma's group, Du's group, and other groups.

elements.content: Compared to the reported rigid polycarboxylate such as terephthalic and 1,3,5-trimesic acid as coligands, the V-shaped polycarboxylates are more likely to induce the helicity or other polymeric chains, which gives us further options to tune the structures and properties. By carefully observing the geometries of V-shaped polycarboxylates and coordination behaviors, we believe that the mixed-ligands of TPOM and V-shaped polycarboxylates can generate unique architectures and topologies. In this paper, TPOM with V-shaped polycarboxlates (H2oba, H2hfipbb, H2dedpa, H2sdba, and H2ddpa (Scheme )) with divalent transition salts were used to solvothermally synthesize seven new coordination polymers, which were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and X-ray crystallography. Crystal structures, topological analyses, and thermal properties of the complexes are presented. In addition, the photochemical and magnetic properties for complexes were studied.

X-ray crystallographic data of 1–7 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted on glass fiber. All measurements were made on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures of complexes 1–7 are solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structure and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using a full-matrix least-squares procedure based on F 2 values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The distributions of peaks in the channels of 1–7 are chemically featureless to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve these issues, the contribution of the electron density by the remaining water molecule is removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The numbers of solvent water molecules are obtained by element analysis and thermogravimetric analysis. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , while the selected bond lengths and angles are given in the (Table S1).

X-ray Crystallography

X-ray crystallographic data of 1-7 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted on glass fiber. All measurements were made on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures of complexes 1-7 are solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structure and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using a full-matrix least-squares procedure based on F 2 values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The distributions of peaks in the channels of 1-7 are chemically featureless to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve these issues, the contribution of the electron density by the remaining water molecule is removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The numbers of solvent water molecules are obtained by element analysis and thermogravimetric analysis. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , while the selected bond lengths and angles are given in the  (Table S1).

X-ray analysis reveals that the structures of complexes 1, 2, and 3 are very similar. These complexes are self-assembled from the TPOM and H2oba with Co­(II), Cd­(II), or Ni­(II) salts, which are further connected into a 3D network. Hence, only the crystal structure of complex 1 is described. The asymmetric unit contains two Co­(II) cations, two oba2– anions, one TPOM ligand, and two coordinated water. As shown in Figure a, two Co­(II) center are all six-coordinated octahedral geometry by four O atoms from two oba2– anions and one coordinated water, and two N atoms from two TPOM. The Co–O lengths are in the range of 2.0361(18)–2.2781(18) Å, and the Co–N lengths are 2.092(2)–2.141(2) Å, which are similar to those found in other Co­(II) complexes.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of {[Co2(TPOM)(oba)2(H2O)2]⋅(H2O)8} n  (1)

X-ray analysis reveals that the structures of complexes 1, 2, and 3 are very similar. These complexes are self-assembled from the TPOM and H2oba with Co(II), Cd(II), or Ni(II) salts, which are further connected into a 3D network. Hence, only the crystal structure of complex 1 is described. The asymmetric unit contains two Co(II) cations, two oba2- anions, one TPOM ligand, and two coordinated water. As shown in Figure a, two Co(II) center are all six-coordinated octahedral geometry by four O atoms from two oba2- anions and one coordinated water, and two N atoms from two TPOM. The Co-O lengths are in the range of 2.0361(18)-2.2781(18) Å, and the Co-N lengths are 2.092(2)-2.141(2) Å, which are similar to those found in other Co(II) complexes.

elements.content: The neighboring Co­(II) ions are linked by TPOM to form an infinitely double-stranded 1D chain containing Co2[(TPOM)0.5]2 loop, and the neighboring Co2[(TPOM)0.5]2 metallocyclic loops arranged almost in vertical (Figure b). Similarly, four oba2– anions connect four Cd­(II) ions to achieve a 64 member [Co4(oba)4] loop exhibiting maximum dimensions of (Co···Co distance and Ccore···Ccore separation) of ∼27.4 × 10.2 Å (Figure c). These two types of loops connect each other further to generate an infinite 3D framework (Figure c). Further inspection shows that there are strong (O–H···O) hydrogen bonds () between coordinated water molecules and carboxyl groups (Figure d). All Co­(II) and TPOM can be regarded as 4-connected nodes, the oba2– anions act as linkers, and complex 1 has a {42·62·75·8}­{42·63·7}­{42·64·73·8} network (Figure e). The most striking feature is that complex 1 contains a self-interpenetrated motif, and the Co2[(TPOM)0.5]2 rings are threaded by Co-oba-Co rods in the same framework.

elements.content: Complex 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system space group of P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of two Co­(II) cations, one TPOM molecule, and two hfipbb2– anions. As shown in Figure a, Co1­(II) ion is four-coordinated with distorted tetrahedral geometry composed of two carboxylic O atoms from two hfipbb2– anions and two N atoms from two TPOM, while Co2­(II) ion is five-coordinated with distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry composed of three carboxylic O atoms from two hfipbb2– anions and two N atoms from two TPOM ligands. The Co–O lengths are in the range of 1.971(3)–2.342(5) Å, and the Co–N lengths are 2.040(4)–2.065(4) Å.

Crystal Structure of {[Co2(TPOM)(hfipbb)2]⋅(H2O)2.5} n  (4)

Complex 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system space group of P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of two Co(II) cations, one TPOM molecule, and two hfipbb2- anions. As shown in Figure a, Co1(II) ion is four-coordinated with distorted tetrahedral geometry composed of two carboxylic O atoms from two hfipbb2- anions and two N atoms from two TPOM, while Co2(II) ion is five-coordinated with distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry composed of three carboxylic O atoms from two hfipbb2- anions and two N atoms from two TPOM ligands. The Co-O lengths are in the range of 1.971(3)-2.342(5) Å, and the Co-N lengths are 2.040(4)-2.065(4) Å.

elements.content: Each Co atom coordinates to two TPOM ligands to form an infinitely 2D sheet along the a axis (Figure b). An interesting feature of this complex is that meso-helical chains exist constructed by hfipbb2– anions and Co­(II) ions, and the distances of neighboring Co atoms are 13.416 and 13.423 Å (Figure c). The 2D sheet further forms a 3D framework via sharing the Co cations with meso-helical chains (Figure d). The Co­(II) ions and TPOM can be regarded as 4-connected nodes and the hfipbb2– anion as linker, and complex 4 has a {63·83}­{64·82}2 topology (Figure e). Further observation demonstrates that complex 4 is also a self-penetrating framework.

elements.content: In complex 5, each Cd­(II) coordinates to TPOM to form infinitely wave-like 2D sheet with quadrilateral grid along the c axis (Figure b). The dedpa2– anions link the sheet to form a 2D network (Figure c). In which each two dedpa2– anion connects one quadrilateral grid to generate a diamond-shaped cavity (Figure d). TPOM ligands are regarded as 4-connected nodes and dedpa2– acted as linkers; complex 5 has a {54·62}­{55·8}2 topology (Figure d), respectively. The large distances between the metal atoms result in large spaces within the network; thus another identical framework occupies this space to generate 2-fold interlocked 2D → 2D network (Figure e).

Co2 also resides in distorted octahedral coordination spheres, but defined by four O atoms from two different sdba2– anions and two coordination water molecules, two N atoms from two TPOM ligands. elements.content: In complex 6, the TPOM ligand adopts a conformation unlike those observed in complexes 1–5, only three pyridyl groups coordinated to Co­(II) ions in one TPOM, and the fourth is free. The −CH2–O spacers adopt orientations that are not fully extended, and the Ccore–CH2–O–C torsion angles vary from 105.894(4)° to 167.923(3)°. As a result, the TPOM ligand adopts a highly irregular conformation with N···Ccore···N angles that vary from 49.921(1)° to 131.985(2)°. TPOM ligands that link Co­(II) ions only formed a 1D chain (Figure b); each binuclear Co cluster links four sdba2– anions to form an infinitely double-stranded 1D chain (Figure c). These two types of chains connect to each other to form a 2D network (Figure d). In fact, two types of coordinated water molecules and carboxyl group link to each other by strong H-bonding (); these H-bonding interactions extend the structure into a 2D bilay network (Figure e). These 2D bilay networks stacked in an AAAA mode (Figure f).

As illustrated in Figure a, Co1 adopts a distorted square pyramid coordination geometry that is formed by four O atoms from four ddpa2– anions and one N atoms from TPOM [Co1–O: 2.0324(18)–2.054(2) Å] and two N atoms from two different TPOM ligands [Co1–N: 2.061(2) Å]. elements.content: Each of two Co­(II) ions is linked by four carboxyl groups to form a paddle-wheel unit, The ddpa2– anions connect paddle-wheel units to generate an infinitely wave-like 2D sheet with square grid. For each TPOM ligand, only two pyridyl groups coordinate to Co­(II) ions belonging to adjacent 2D sheets to give a 3D framework (Figure b), and the uncoordinated pyridyl groups occupied part of the space of the framework. But the potential voids are large enough to be filled via mutual interpenetration of an independent equivalent framework, generating a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure c). Topology analysis reveals that the structure can be represented as pcu network (Figure d).

elements.content: TPOM and semirigid V-shaped ligands have longer arms, and the corresponding metal–organic coordination polymers can generate spacious voids, cavities, or channels easily, which caused the forming of entanglements. Self-interpenetrated and interlocked systems are extremely active subjects of the entangled systems. As far as we know, most of the TPOM-based polymers are interpenetrated or interlocked systems. In the case of TPOM-based polymers containing semirigid V-shaped dicarboxylates, the arms of TPOM or semirigid V-shaped ligands can freely rotate in a certain degree to meet the requirement of coordination geometries, so various interpenetrated modes, such as self-penetrated, interlocked, or polycatanated can be observed.

elements.content: The conformation of TPOM plays an important role in the formation of the various polymers. According to the report by Wuest, the distortion can be assessed by comparing the N–Ccore–N angles defined by the central carbon atom of the pentaerythrityl core (Ccore) and the nitrogen atoms of the pyridyl groups, as well as the Ccore–CH2–O–C torsion angles. These angles are shown in Table . The results show that TPOM ligands deviate totally from tetrahedral geometry by a varying degree. Furthermore, the -CH2O- spacers that connect each pyridyl group to the Ccore adopt conformations that are not fully extended, so they have distinctly different coordination geometries and thus give rise to different frameworks and topologies.
elements.clean_text:
Conformations of TPOM in Complexes 1-7 

The conformation of TPOM plays an important role in the formation of the various polymers. According to the report by Wuest, the distortion can be assessed by comparing the N-Ccore-N angles defined by the central carbon atom of the pentaerythrityl core (Ccore) and the nitrogen atoms of the pyridyl groups, as well as the Ccore-CH2-O-C torsion angles. These angles are shown in Table . The results show that TPOM ligands deviate totally from tetrahedral geometry by a varying degree. Furthermore, the -CH2O- spacers that connect each pyridyl group to the Ccore adopt conformations that are not fully extended, so they have distinctly different coordination geometries and thus give rise to different frameworks and topologies.

To estimate the stability of the coordination architectures, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). Complex 1 is less stable with a 11.23% (calcd 11.48%) weight loss of lattice water and DMF molecules from 20 to 240 °C, and the framework collapsed at 370 °C. For complex 2, the weight loss of 4.35% (calcd 4.77%) observed from 20 to 95 °C corresponds to the departure of the lattice water, and then a rapid weight loss of 6.85% (calcd 7.25%) is observed from 100 to 225 °C due to the loss of DMF molecules; the structure then decomposed starting at 380 °C. Complex 3 is similar to complex 1; a weight loss of 8.17% (calcd 7.52%) was observed from 20 to 110 °C due to the release of lattice water molecules, and then the structure decomposed starting at 370 °C. Complex 4 is a 2.65% (calcd 2.03%) weight loss of lattice molecules before 100 °C; the framework begins to decompose until 405 °C. Complex 5 loses four lattice water molecules at 20–100 °C with a weight loss of 4.85% (calcd 4.94%). Then a rapid weight loss of 10.15% (calcd 10.03%) is observed from 110 to 190 °C due to loss of DMF molecules, and the framework collapses at 380 °C. Complex 6 is less stable with a 4.20% (calcd 4.29%) weight loss of lattice and coordinated water molecules from 20 to 120 °C, and the structure then decomposed starting at 370 °C. Complex 7 is stable and the framework collapses at 400 °C. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1–7. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in the (Figures S4–S10). The results demonstrate that the experimental PXRD patterns perfectly match the simulated patterns based on the single-crystal X-ray data.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis and PXRD Results

To estimate the stability of the coordination architectures, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). Complex 1 is less stable with a 11.23% (calcd 11.48%) weight loss of lattice water and DMF molecules from 20 to 240 °C, and the framework collapsed at 370 °C. For complex 2, the weight loss of 4.35% (calcd 4.77%) observed from 20 to 95 °C corresponds to the departure of the lattice water, and then a rapid weight loss of 6.85% (calcd 7.25%) is observed from 100 to 225 °C due to the loss of DMF molecules; the structure then decomposed starting at 380 °C. Complex 3 is similar to complex 1; a weight loss of 8.17% (calcd 7.52%) was observed from 20 to 110 °C due to the release of lattice water molecules, and then the structure decomposed starting at 370 °C. Complex 4 is a 2.65% (calcd 2.03%) weight loss of lattice molecules before 100 °C; the framework begins to decompose until 405 °C. Complex 5 loses four lattice water molecules at 20-100 °C with a weight loss of 4.85% (calcd 4.94%). Then a rapid weight loss of 10.15% (calcd 10.03%) is observed from 110 to 190 °C due to loss of DMF molecules, and the framework collapses at 380 °C. Complex 6 is less stable with a 4.20% (calcd 4.29%) weight loss of lattice and coordinated water molecules from 20 to 120 °C, and the structure then decomposed starting at 370 °C. Complex 7 is stable and the framework collapses at 400 °C. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1-7. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in the  (Figures S4-S10). The results demonstrate that the experimental PXRD patterns perfectly match the simulated patterns based on the single-crystal X-ray data.

elements.content: The luminescent properties of free ligands as well as complexes 2 and 5 in the solid state at room temperature were studied (Figure ). No obvious emission band is observed about the free H2oba under the same experimental condition. The curve of free TPOM ligand shows an infirm emission with wavelength from 420 to 475 nm (λmax = 450 nm), and H2endb shows an emission with wavelength from 380 to 550 nm (λmax = 430 nm). Complex 2 exhibits a small blue shift compared with that of TPOM, the emission peaks at 398 nm (λex = 345 nm). Complex 5 exhibits a small red shift compared with that of H2endb, the emission peak is at 435 nm (λex= 354 nm), which originate from intraligand or ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT). In addition, the UV–vis absorption spectra of compounds 1, 3, 4, 6, and 7 were carried out in the crystalline state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , TPOM, H2oba, and H2sdba show intense absorption peaks at 200–300 nm, which can be ascribed to π–π* transitions of the ligands. Energy bands of complex 1 (460–580 nm), 3 (350–450 nm and 550–750 nm), 4 (430–650 nm), 6 (460–570 nm), and 7 (520–650 nm) are assigned as d–d transitions, while higher energy bands from 300 to 350 nm are assigned as metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) transitions.

The curve of free TPOM ligand shows an infirm emission with wavelength from 420 to 475 nm (λmax = 450 nm), and H2endb shows an emission with wavelength from 380 to 550 nm (λmax = 430 nm). Complex 2 exhibits a small blue shift compared with that of TPOM, the emission peaks at 398 nm (λex = 345 nm). Complex 5 exhibits a small red shift compared with that of H2endb, the emission peak is at 435 nm (λex= 354 nm), which originate from intraligand or ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT). In addition, the UV-vis absorption spectra of compounds 1, 3, 4, 6, and 7 were carried out in the crystalline state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , TPOM, H2oba, and H2sdba show intense absorption peaks at 200-300 nm, which can be ascribed to π-π* transitions of the ligands. Energy bands of complex 1 (460-580 nm), 3 (350-450 nm and 550-750 nm), 4 (430-650 nm), 6 (460-570 nm), and 7 (520-650 nm) are assigned as d-d transitions, while higher energy bands from 300 to 350 nm are assigned as metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) transitions.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 6 were investigated in the 2.0–300 K range at 2000 Oe. For 6 (Figure ), the thermal evolution of χm –1 obeys Curie–Weiss law, χm = C/(T – θ) over the whole temperature range from 300 to 2 K with Weiss constant, θ, of −18.86 K and the Curie constant, C, of −6.9 cm3·K·mol–1. The χm T value at 300 K is 6.35 cm3·K·mol–1, which is much higher than the expected value (3.75 cm3·K·mol–1) of two magnetically isolated spin-only Co (II) ions (S = 3/2, g = 2.0), which indicates that an important contribution of the orbital angular momentum typical for the 4T 1g ground term is involved. When the temperature is decreased from 300 to 2 K, the χm T value continuously decreases and reaches a local minimum of 0.58 cm3·K·mol–1 at 2 K. This behavior indicates a dominant antiferromagnetic interaction between the Co­(II) ions in the structures.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Property of Complex 6 

The magnetic properties of 6 were investigated in the 2.0-300 K range at 2000 Oe. For 6 (Figure ), the thermal evolution of χm -1 obeys Curie-Weiss law, χm = C/(T - θ) over the whole temperature range from 300 to 2 K with Weiss constant, θ, of -18.86 K and the Curie constant, C, of -6.9 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1. The χm T value at 300 K is 6.35 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, which is much higher than the expected value (3.75 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1) of two magnetically isolated spin-only Co (II) ions (S = 3/2, g = 2.0), which indicates that an important contribution of the orbital angular momentum typical for the 4T 1g  ground term is involved. When the temperature is decreased from 300 to 2 K, the χm T value continuously decreases and reaches a local minimum of 0.58 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 2 K. This behavior indicates a dominant antiferromagnetic interaction between the Co(II) ions in the structures.

The conformation of TPOM adopts distorted tetrahedral orientation and plays a crucial role in the formation of various polymers. These seven complexes not only show aesthetic diversity of coordinative frameworks, but also can be used for the design of functional materials. elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, as we expected, the self-assembly of TPOM and V-shaped polycarboxylates is an effective method to generate unique architectures and topologies. The conformation of TPOM adopts distorted tetrahedral orientation and plays a crucial role in the formation of various polymers. These seven complexes not only show aesthetic diversity of coordinative frameworks, but also can be used for the design of functional materials. It is anticipated that more complexes containing V-shaped polycarboxylates with various interesting networks as well as physical properties will be synthesized.

cln_elements.content:
Complex 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system space group of P21/c. The asymmetric unit consists of two Co­(II) cations, one TPOM molecule, and two hfipbb2– anions. As shown in Figure a, Co1­(II) ion is four-coordinated with distorted tetrahedral geometry composed of two carboxylic O atoms from two hfipbb2– anions and two N atoms from two TPOM, while Co2­(II) ion is five-coordinated with distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry composed of three carboxylic O atoms from two hfipbb2– anions and two N atoms from two TPOM ligands. The Co–O lengths are in the range of 1.971(3)–2.342(5) Å, and the Co–N lengths are 2.040(4)–2.065(4) Å.

Crystal Structure of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(TPOM)­(dedpa)<sub>2</sub>]·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>·(DMF)<sub>2</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

Complex 5 is a 2-fold interlocked 2D → 2D network, and the crystal structure is solved in the space group C2/c. As depicted in Figure a, there are two types of coordination environments around the Cd­(II) ions, one TPOM molecule, two dedpa2– anions. Two Cd­(II) ions have a similar distorted octahedral geometry with four carboxylic O atoms from two dedpa2– anions and two N atoms from two TPOM ligands. The Cd–O lengths are 2.258(4)–2.444(5) Å, and the Cd–N lengths are 2.275(4) and 2.289(5) Å.

Thermal Analysis and PXRD Results

To estimate the stability of the coordination architectures, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). Complex 1 is less stable with a 11.23% (calcd 11.48%) weight loss of lattice water and DMF molecules from 20 to 240 °C, and the framework collapsed at 370 °C. For complex 2, the weight loss of 4.35% (calcd 4.77%) observed from 20 to 95 °C corresponds to the departure of the lattice water, and then a rapid weight loss of 6.85% (calcd 7.25%) is observed from 100 to 225 °C due to the loss of DMF molecules; the structure then decomposed starting at 380 °C. Complex 3 is similar to complex 1; a weight loss of 8.17% (calcd 7.52%) was observed from 20 to 110 °C due to the release of lattice water molecules, and then the structure decomposed starting at 370 °C. Complex 4 is a 2.65% (calcd 2.03%) weight loss of lattice molecules before 100 °C; the framework begins to decompose until 405 °C. Complex 5 loses four lattice water molecules at 20–100 °C with a weight loss of 4.85% (calcd 4.94%). Then a rapid weight loss of 10.15% (calcd 10.03%) is observed from 110 to 190 °C due to loss of DMF molecules, and the framework collapses at 380 °C. Complex 6 is less stable with a 4.20% (calcd 4.29%) weight loss of lattice and coordinated water molecules from 20 to 120 °C, and the structure then decomposed starting at 370 °C. Complex 7 is stable and the framework collapses at 400 °C. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1–7. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in the (Figures S4–S10). The results demonstrate that the experimental PXRD patterns perfectly match the simulated patterns based on the single-crystal X-ray data.

Photochemical Properties

The luminescent properties of free ligands as well as complexes 2 and 5 in the solid state at room temperature were studied (Figure ). No obvious emission band is observed about the free H2oba under the same experimental condition. The curve of free TPOM ligand shows an infirm emission with wavelength from 420 to 475 nm (λmax = 450 nm), and H2endb shows an emission with wavelength from 380 to 550 nm (λmax = 430 nm). Complex 2 exhibits a small blue shift compared with that of TPOM, the emission peaks at 398 nm (λex = 345 nm). Complex 5 exhibits a small red shift compared with that of H2endb, the emission peak is at 435 nm (λex= 354 nm), which originate from intraligand or ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT). In addition, the UV–vis absorption spectra of compounds 1, 3, 4, 6, and 7 were carried out in the crystalline state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , TPOM, H2oba, and H2sdba show intense absorption peaks at 200–300 nm, which can be ascribed to π–π* transitions of the ligands. Energy bands of complex 1 (460–580 nm), 3 (350–450 nm and 550–750 nm), 4 (430–650 nm), 6 (460–570 nm), and 7 (520–650 nm) are assigned as d–d transitions, while higher energy bands from 300 to 350 nm are assigned as metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) transitions.

Magnetic Property of Complex <bold>6</bold>

The magnetic properties of 6 were investigated in the 2.0–300 K range at 2000 Oe. For 6 (Figure ), the thermal evolution of χm –1 obeys Curie–Weiss law, χm = C/(T – θ) over the whole temperature range from 300 to 2 K with Weiss constant, θ, of −18.86 K and the Curie constant, C, of −6.9 cm3·K·mol–1. The χm T value at 300 K is 6.35 cm3·K·mol–1, which is much higher than the expected value (3.75 cm3·K·mol–1) of two magnetically isolated spin-only Co (II) ions (S = 3/2, g = 2.0), which indicates that an important contribution of the orbital angular momentum typical for the 4T 1g ground term is involved. When the temperature is decreased from 300 to 2 K, the χm T value continuously decreases and reaches a local minimum of 0.58 cm3·K·mol–1 at 2 K. This behavior indicates a dominant antiferromagnetic interaction between the Co­(II) ions in the structures.

Then a rapid weight loss of 10.15% (calcd 10.03%) is observed from 110 to 190 °C due to loss of DMF molecules, and the framework collapses at 380 °C. Complex 6 is less stable with a 4.20% (calcd 4.29%) weight loss of lattice and coordinated water molecules from 20 to 120 °C, and the structure then decomposed starting at 370 °C. Complex 7 is stable and the framework collapses at 400 °C. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1-7. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in the  (Figures S4-S10). The results demonstrate that the experimental PXRD patterns perfectly match the simulated patterns based on the single-crystal X-ray data.

Photochemical Properties

The luminescent properties of free ligands as well as complexes 2 and 5 in the solid state at room temperature were studied (Figure ). No obvious emission band is observed about the free H2oba under the same experimental condition. The curve of free TPOM ligand shows an infirm emission with wavelength from 420 to 475 nm (λmax = 450 nm), and H2endb shows an emission with wavelength from 380 to 550 nm (λmax = 430 nm). Complex 2 exhibits a small blue shift compared with that of TPOM, the emission peaks at 398 nm (λex = 345 nm). Complex 5 exhibits a small red shift compared with that of H2endb, the emission peak is at 435 nm (λex= 354 nm), which originate from intraligand or ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT). In addition, the UV-vis absorption spectra of compounds 1, 3, 4, 6, and 7 were carried out in the crystalline state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , TPOM, H2oba, and H2sdba show intense absorption peaks at 200-300 nm, which can be ascribed to π-π* transitions of the ligands. Energy bands of complex 1 (460-580 nm), 3 (350-450 nm and 550-750 nm), 4 (430-650 nm), 6 (460-570 nm), and 7 (520-650 nm) are assigned as d-d transitions, while higher energy bands from 300 to 350 nm are assigned as metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) transitions. 

Magnetic Property of Complex 6 

The magnetic properties of 6 were investigated in the 2.0-300 K range at 2000 Oe. For 6 (Figure ), the thermal evolution of χm -1 obeys Curie-Weiss law, χm = C/(T - θ) over the whole temperature range from 300 to 2 K with Weiss constant, θ, of -18.86 K and the Curie constant, C, of -6.9 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1. The χm T value at 300 K is 6.35 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, which is much higher than the expected value (3.75 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1) of two magnetically isolated spin-only Co (II) ions (S = 3/2, g = 2.0), which indicates that an important contribution of the orbital angular momentum typical for the 4T 1g  ground term is involved. When the temperature is decreased from 300 to 2 K, the χm T value continuously decreases and reaches a local minimum of 0.58 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 2 K. This behavior indicates a dominant antiferromagnetic interaction between the Co(II) ions in the structures.
